title: Criminal gang 'raided AMBULANCES for life-saving equipment'
text:
A gang accused of conspiring to steal lifesaving medical equipment from ambulances before selling it on for profit have appeared in court.

They were charged after more than 300 defibrillators as well as drugs and other items were stolen from response vehicles and buildings in a series of raids.

The life-saving equipment was taken between September 2016 and August 2017 in towns across Kent including Thanet, Herne Bay, Ashford, Northfleet and Chatham.

Folkestone Magistrates' Court was told an organised crime group operated a patient transport business and first aid company and sold second-hand medical equipment.

A gang accused of conspiring to steal lifesaving medical equipment from ambulances before selling it on for profit have appeared in court (stock image)

Leanne James, prosecuting, said: 'A number of individuals committed burglaries from ambulance stations and medical establishments, during the course of which, medical equipment and drugs were stolen.

'They were sold through the medical equipment company making the enterprise very huge profits.

'Other individuals have been involved in the laundering of money generated through that business.

'It's an enterprise where, we say, all of the defendants are inextricably linked to each other.'

Kevin Buck, 52, of Norwich, Norfolk, was charged with receiving stolen goods and entering into a money laundering arrangement and was granted conditional bail.

Ash McKee, 50, of Telford, Shropshire, and Nicholas Hamill, 35, and John Moys, 46, both of HMP Elmley, were charged with theft, conspiracy to burgle, robbery, handling stolen goods, laundering the proceeds of crime.

They were charged after more than 300 defibrillators (stock image) as well as drugs and other items were stolen from response vehicles and buildings in a series of raids

McKee was granted conditional bail while Hamill and Moys were remanded in custody.

Mark Goldfinch, 43, of Herne Bay, Kent, was charged with conspiracy to steal and burgle and was granted conditional bail.

Joseph Meizen, 28, of HMP Full Sutton, Yorkshire, was charged with robbery and conspiracy to steal and burgle and was remanded in custody.

Jade Ford, 29, also of Herne Bay, Derek Jackson, 52, and 37-year-old Vanessa Jackson, both of Whitstable, Kent, were charged with entering into a money laundering arrangement and were all granted conditional bail.

Ruby MacGregor, 29, of Canterbury, Kent, was charged with handling stolen goods, did not appear before magistrates.

All the defendants are due to appear at Canterbury Crown Court on November 11.
